conclusion: Analyze the path of light rays through the semicircular glass brick.
The semicircular glass brick has a radius R, and the critical angle is γ.
Light rays strike the flat base at an angle π - γ relative to the horizontal plane.
Light rays refract according to Snell's Law when entering the glass brick.
Snell's Law: n1 sin(θ1) = n2 sin(θ2), where n1 = 1, θ1 = π - γ.
Critical angle γ is defined by sin(γ) = 1/n2.
Total internal reflection occurs if angle of incidence is ≥ γ.
Light rays striking the curved surface at angles ≥ γ undergo total internal reflection.
Light rays passing directly through the base strike the curved surface at angles < γ.
Critical point is where light ray is tangent to the curved surface at the semicircle's edge.
Width of the base through which light passes is the chord length of the semicircle.
Angle subtended by the chord at the center is 2γ.
Chord length L is calculated using L = 2R sin(γ).
Width of the base through which light passes is 2R sin(γ).
